SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: What does the word “crouched” mean as it is used in paragraph 6?

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: In paragraph 9, what is the most likely reason Riley stays quiet as she and Craig walk home?

A.Choice: She is thinking about how well she played hockey.

B.Choice: She is upset with Craig because he hurt her back.

C.Choice: She is thinking about how to get skates for Craig.

D.Choice: She is tired from skating in the hockey game.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: What does paragraph 12 help the reader understand about Craig?

A.Choice: Craig is too young to learn how to skate.

B.Choice: Craig is very excited about learning to skate.

C.Choice: Craig is unable to take the skates off by himself.

D.Choice: Craig is worried that his sister will take the skates back.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: In paragraph 16, what does the phrase “like being a snail” help the reader to understand about Craig?

B.Choice: He moves in a crooked line.

C.Choice: He searches for a place to hide.

D.Choice: He looks like all the other skaters.

SubTopics: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.
Content: Which sentence best describes how paragraph 6 relates to paragraph 23?

A.Choice: Paragraph 6 provides a problem and paragraph 23 provides a solution.

B.Choice: Paragraph 6 asks a question and paragraph 23 provides an answer.

C.Choice: Paragraph 6 provides a cause and paragraph 23 shows an effect.

D.Choice: Paragraph 6 provides similarities and paragraph 23 shows differences.

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: Which sentence best describes a central message of the story?

A.Choice: Change is normal and an important part of life.

B.Choice: Friendships often become stronger over time.

C.Choice: New experiences can be exciting and wonderful.

D.Choice: Natural talent is more important than practice.

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: According to paragraph 5, what happens right before thunder can be heard?

A.Choice: Little drops of water move around in the sky.

B.Choice: Dark clouds appear in the sky.

C.Choice: Rain droplets start to fall from the clouds.

D.Choice: The air spreads because of heat from lightning.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: What is the main idea of paragraph 6?

A.Choice: Lightning can reach from the sky to the ground.

B.Choice: A bolt of lightning can travel up to nine miles.

C.Choice: Flashes of lightning can jump from one cloud to another.

D.Choice: Lightning can move over large distances very quickly.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Use information gained from illustrations (e.g., maps, photographs) and the words in a text to demonstrate understanding of the text (e.g., where, when, why, and how key events occur).
Content: Which idea from the passage does the second illustration best support?

A.Choice: Lightning can be helpful for nature.

C.Choice: Lightning appears in different ways in the sky.

D.Choice: Lightning may strike before or after it rains.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: What does the word “nutrient” mean as it is used in paragraph 10?

SubTopics: Use text features and search tools (e.g., key words, sidebars, hyperlinks) to locate information relevant to a given topic efficiently.
Content: Which question does the section “Fast Facts” help to answer?

A.Choice: How does lightning help the earth?

B.Choice: How is lightning different in the summer?

C.Choice: How is electricity created in clouds?

D.Choice: How can someone avoid an electrical shock?

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Which sentence shows a cause and effect relationship that is stated in the passage?

A.Choice: People see lightning before they hear thunder.

B.Choice: Wildfires can start when lightning touches the ground.

C.Choice: Heat from electricity is hotter than the surface of the sun.

D.Choice: Lightning bolts can hit tall trees and buildings.

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: In the passage “Meet the Teacher,” how does Tatenda change from paragraph 1 to paragraph 5? Use two details from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: What is the main idea of the passage “Meet the Teacher”? Use two details from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Just the Right Gift,” how is paragraph 12 important to the rest of the story? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Just the Right Gift,” what do the details in paragraphs 17 through 21 show about the mother? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: What is a central message in “[Excerpt from] Just the Right Gift”? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: What does the sentence “Don't get too close, or you'll be sorry!” mean as it is used in paragraph 1 of the passage? Use two details from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: In the passage “Don't Touch Me!,” how do most plants protect themselves from danger? What happens as a result of these plants being touched? Use details from the passage to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• tell how most plants protect themselves from danger
• explain what happens as a result of these plants being touched
• use details from the passage to support your response
